awd_titl_txt: A Professional Development Workshop Series for STEM Faculty
awd_abstract_narration:
The Committee on Equal Opportunities in Sciences and Engineering has urged the National Science Foundation to utilize its convening power to impact its broadening participation portfolio through workshops and online resources. The planned STEM professional development workshop series led by the Fielding Graduate University in partnership with Historically Black Colleges and Universities will address two broadening participation challenges: the lack of diverse STEM faculty in leadership positions and the dearth of culturally relevant leadership development opportunities and resources that can support women faculty of color. 

The project aims to implement a state-of-the-art professional development approach through convenings that integrate leadership development, scholarship, coalition building and professional/personal wellness to have a systemic impact on broadening participation. The workshop series will consist of three major convenings: 
1. Leadership Academy, designed to increase leadership self-efficacy of STEM women faculty of color through cutting-edge in-person and virtual culturally-responsive leadership development opportunities, 
2. Author Development Institute, designed as a four-day intensive, in-person training with year-long follow-up support to increase the scholarly contributions of STEM women faculty of color to the STEM reform discourse, and 
3. Leader Wellness Workshop, designed as a two-day capstone experience that prioritizes well-being as an essential component for effective leadership development and advancement. 

The work of this project holds great promise for addressing the persisting disparities related to women of color in academic leadership positions in STEM. This project will offer a postgraduate certificate in leadership studies and enrich opportunities for increasing the submission and success rates of STEM leadership/reform publications by women of color. This project will develop a cadre of academic STEM leaders who have been empowered to lead broadening participation efforts and address diversity challenges at a national level.

This project is co-funded by the Directorate of Biological Sciences (BIO), the Directorate of Geosciences (GEO), the Office of Integrative Activities (OIA), and the Directorate of Education and Human Resources (EHR) with significant support from the NSF's Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program, which targets increasing the number of historically underrepresented minority faculty in STEM disciplines and the Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP), which enhances STEM education and research at HBCUs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Women of color comprise an important source of talent for our nation’s STEM enterprise. However, women of color, particularly those at Historically Black Institutions, are largely excluded from the intellectual networks and denied access to the resources that can support their career advancement. This reality all too often results in women of color leaving HBCUs for Predominantly White Institutions, leaving the academy, or leaving STEM altogether. This has been particularly true during the most recent pandemic years. When the academy loses women of color, our nation loses the full dimension and cultural acumen needed for scientific discoveries, innovations, and educational advances to both give rise to more competitively trained and diverse future generations of scientists and generate more meaningful social impact (Portia, Ltd., 2012). Redressing this trend requires that we first admit to the existence of two systemic barriers within the academy – the lack of minoritized STEM women faculty in leadership positions and the dearth of culturally relevant leadership development opportunities that can appropriately support them.

The overarching goal of the project was to implement a tripartite STEM professional development program that not only integrates leadership development, but also coalition building, authorship, and well-being into a comprehensive and bold approach that supports, accelerates, and impacts the career advancement of STEM women of color. Specifically, this project has designed and deployed a unique, culturally responsive platform that targets the professional, personal, and spiritual needs of women of color. The objectives by which this goal was achieved were: (1) increasing leadership self-efficacy of STEM women faculty of color through cutting-edge, culturally responsive leadership development programming (Leader Academy/Leadership Colloquium), (2) increasing the capacity of STEM women faculty of color to make scholarly contributions to the national undergraduate STEM reform discourse (Authorship Development Institute/Keystroke Writing Institute), and (3) prioritizing well-being as an essential component for effective professional development for women of color (Leader Well-Being Workshop/STEM Women of Color Conclave®).

This culturally responsive leadership development for STEM women faculty of color holistically captured the lived experiences of women of color and translated them into effective professional and leadership development practices for the undergraduate STEM reform community, at large.

Since its inception, the current project has empowered over one hundred STEM women faculty of color, primarily from HBCUs. Reported levels of leadership self-efficacy among this group increased significantly over the life of the project period, particularly among STEM women faculty of color who were engaged at multiple points throughout the project period. National visibility is another important outcome of the current project. To date, culturally responsive components of the current project have been replicated in various academic spaces across the country, including scholarly writing retreats on HBCU and non-HBCU campuses and campus - and national-level convenings of women of color in the STEM disciplines. Taken together, these project outcomes form a foundation that is ideally situated for expansion and scale. 

 


Last Modified: 12/28/2023
Modified by: Orlando L Taylor
